name: Measurement, Statistics & the Calculus of Society
description:
This network traces the intellectual lineage from probability theory's mathematical foundations through the ambitious project of 'social physics'—the attempt to apply mathematical methods to understand human society. Beginning with Laplace's foundational work on probability and the 'calculus of chance,' through Quetelet's vision of the 'average man' and statistical laws governing society, to Fisher's modern statistical inference—this network reveals how the dream of a mathematical science of society shaped the development of statistics itself.

The period (c. 1750-1950) encompasses the transformation of probability from a tool for gambling into a universal framework for scientific reasoning, the controversial application of quantitative methods to social phenomena, and the emergence of statistics as a discipline with profound implications for science, policy, and society.
author: HistoryNet Contributors

subgroups.name: French Probabilists
subgroups.description: Laplace and the French school of probability theory (1750-1840), including contributions to Bayesian reasoning, the central limit theorem, and applications to astronomy and social phenomena

subgroups.name: German Error Theorists
subgroups.description: Gauss and the German tradition of error theory, least squares, and the normal distribution applied to astronomical observation

subgroups.name: Social Statisticians
subgroups.description: Quetelet and the international movement to apply statistical methods to social phenomena—crime, suicide, population, moral statistics, and the 'average man' concept (1830-1880)

subgroups.name: British Biometricians
subgroups.description: Galton, Pearson, and the biometric school developing correlation, regression, and statistical methods for studying heredity and evolution (1880-1930)

subgroups.name: Modern Statistical Inference
subgroups.description: Fisher, Neyman, and the development of modern statistical inference—hypothesis testing, maximum likelihood, experimental design (1920-1950)

scope.exclusionNotes: Excluding pure mathematicians without statistical applications, and economists unless directly contributing to statistical methodology. Including eugenics figures where historically relevant to statistical development, with appropriate context about this problematic legacy.
